Method Detail

freeze

void freeze()
If an object is "thawed" then calling freeze will try to disable the optional methods. An implementing class does not have to honour this but the programmer should assume that all optional methods will now throw IllegalStateException.

freeze

void freeze(java.lang.String optimise)
The point at which an object is frozen is also a natural point at which to optimise the object, meaning that the object is restructured to improve some aspect of the runtime behaviour. This method passes a string, whose interpretation is up to the implementation.

However, here is a patten that implementors are welcome to adopt which will cope with many situations and is quite easy to code. See com.steelypip.powerups.common.OptimiseOptions.

  • a leading digit determines the time/work budgeted for optimising, with "0" meaning no time.
  • different aspects of optimisation are signalled with a letter: F for fast, S for small, C for compliant and G for debuggable.
  • the aspects are listed in groups of equal priority, separated by a '>' e.g. "FG>S", fast and debuggable more important than space but as important as each other.
  • if an aspect is omitted it is given a default priority with C being assigned the top priority and the others being assigned the lowest priority. e.g. "F>S" is the same as "C>F>S>G".

    For example the optimsation options of the GNU C compiler gcc would be represented like this:

  • -O0 is "0", don't optimise, also "".
  • -O1 is "1", a balanced optimisation (C>FSG).
  • -O2 is "2FS", optimisations that may sacrifice debuggability (C>FS>G).
  • -O3 is "3F", more optimisations that may sacrifice space and debuggability (C>F>SG).
  • -Ofast is "3F>C", optimisations that may not be strictly standards compliant (F>C>SG).
  • -Os is "2S>F", level 2 optimisations that prioritise space over speed (C>S>F>G).
  • -Og is "2G>FS", level 2 optimisations that do not compromise debuggability (C>G>FS).

    Parameters:
    optimise -
